com.ieireference.system.drawing.swing

Class SwingLAFID

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ieireference.system.drawing.swing.SwingLAFID

  • public final class SwingLAFID
extends java.lang.Object
    Represents a class ID for LookAndFeel for Java Swing. Each String have the javadoc of classes LookAndFeel (LAF) without author.

    • Field Detail

      • System

        public static final java.lang.String System
        Returns the name of the LookAndFeel class that implements the native system look and feel if there is one, otherwise the name of the default cross platform LookAndFeel class. This value can be overridden by setting the swing.systemlaf system property.

      • Windows

        public static final java.lang.String Windows
        Implements the Windows95/98/NT/2000 Look and Feel. UI classes not implemented specifically for Windows will default to those implemented in Basic.

        Warning: Serialized objects of this class will not be compatible with future Swing releases. The current serialization support is appropriate for short term storage or RMI between applications running the same version of Swing. A future release of Swing will provide support for long term persistence.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • WindowsClassic

        public static final java.lang.String WindowsClassic
        Implements the Windows95/98/ME/NT/2000 Look and Feel.

        Warning: Serialized objects of this class will not be compatible with future Swing releases. The current serialization support is appropriate for short term storage or RMI between applications running the same version of Swing. A future release of Swing will provide support for long term persistence.

        Since:
        1.5
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • Metal

        public static final java.lang.String Metal
        The Java Look and Feel, otherwise known as Metal.

        Each of the ComponentUIs provided by MetalLookAndFeel derives its behavior from the defaults table. Unless otherwise noted each of the ComponentUI implementations in this package document the set of defaults they use. Unless otherwise noted the defaults are installed at the time installUI is invoked, and follow the recommendations outlined in LookAndFeel for installing defaults.

        MetalLookAndFeel derives it's color palette and fonts from MetalTheme. The default theme is OceanTheme. The theme can be changed using the setCurrentTheme method, refer to it for details on changing the theme. Prior to 1.5 the default theme was DefaultMetalTheme. The system property "swing.metalTheme" can be set to "steel" to indicate the default should be DefaultMetalTheme.

        Warning: Serialized objects of this class will not be compatible with future Swing releases. The current serialization support is appropriate for short term storage or RMI between applications running the same version of Swing. As of 1.4, support for long term storage of all JavaBeans™ has been added to the java.beans package. Please see XMLEncoder.

        See Also:
        MetalTheme, DefaultMetalTheme, OceanTheme, Constant Field Values

      • CDE_Motif

        public static final java.lang.String CDE_Motif
        Implements the Motif Look and Feel. UI classes not implemented specifically for Motif will default to those implemented in Basic.

        Warning: Serialized objects of this class will not be compatible with future Swing releases. The current serialization support is appropriate for short term storage or RMI between applications running the same version of Swing. A future release of Swing will provide support for long term persistence.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • applyLAF

        public static void applyLAF(java.lang.String laf)
                     throws java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                            java.lang.InstantiationException,
                            java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                            javax.swing.UnsupportedLookAndFeelException
        You can apply LAF here.
        Parameters:
        laf - Use the IDs of class.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - if the LookAndFeel class could not be found
        java.lang.InstantiationException - if a new instance of the class couldn't be created
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException - if the class or initializer isn't accessible
        javax.swing.UnsupportedLookAndFeelException - if lnf.isSupportedLookAndFeel() is false
        java.lang.ClassCastException - if className does not identify a class that extends LookAndFeel

      • applyLAF

        public static void applyLAF(java.lang.String laf,
                            java.awt.Component c)
                     throws java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                            java.lang.InstantiationException,
                            java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                            javax.swing.UnsupportedLookAndFeelException
        You can apply LAF here. Apply and update component.
        Parameters:
        laf - Use the IDs of class.
        c - the component to update Look And Feel.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - if the LookAndFeel class could not be found
        java.lang.InstantiationException - if a new instance of the class couldn't be created
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException - if the class or initializer isn't accessible
        javax.swing.UnsupportedLookAndFeelException - if lnf.isSupportedLookAndFeel() is false
        java.lang.ClassCastException - if className does not identify a class that extends LookAndFeel
